let's talk about the last aspect of it
which is sort of the operational
stability okay now Amazon eks is
available in 13 regions around the world
with support for more coming at Amazon
scale how do we roll out support for
kubernetes to a particular region or if
we were to patch a particular reason for
a newer version of kubernetes how do we
do that well the concept of region is
AWS has multiple regions around the
world and this is a physical location
around the world where data centers are
co-located now each region is
distributed across multiple Easy's or
availability zones and that gives you
the ability to build applications that
are resilient now what we do is for
deployment purposes if you look at it
you know these are showing two regions
and each region has multiple
availability zones now for deployment
purpose each region or other eat
availability zone is split up into
multiple cells and each cell essentially
the capacity of a cell is defined by the
number of clusters that can be created
in that cell ok so now when we are doing
a deployment a major deployment of
kubernetes say a new version or updating
a new version then we deploy to a cell
we run our health checks make sure the
clusters are up and running make sure
all our health checks are passing if
that is successful then we move on to
the next cell
and then next cell and then next cell so
on so forth so that gives us you know
there are a lot of advantages for that
sort of an architecture and I'll talk
about that in a second but essentially
once one availability zone and all the
cells in that availability zone are
updated then we move to the next
availability zone and so on so forth and
then the next region so that kind of
gives you the ability to really do a
cell based architecture essentially so
what are some of the advantages of such
a cell based architecture well the first
advantage really is it gives you a lower
blast radius and at Amazon we always
think in terms of plaster ideas
basically that if there is a problem
happening somewhere how big the blast
radius is how much of an impact is going
to cause to the customer now breaking up
a service into multiple cells helps
reduce the blast radius because cells
essentially represent the bulkhead that
provide containment for many common
failure scenarios so if a failure really
happens know within a cell and is
contained within the cell so that the
other cells are not impacted now when
properly isolated from each other this
is the way the cells are being done
cells have the failure commit
commitments similar to regions so if the
cell goes bad then only the customers in
that cell will be impacted and we always
think in terms of how to further reduce
the blast radius of a cell cell based
architectures scale out rather than
scale up and are inherently more
scalable so it gives you a lot more
scalability in terms of how many
customers can be deployed in a
particular region it also gives you
higher testability because the cab size
of cells is well understood and tested
for maximal you know behavior that how
much it can scale so we know exactly how
much it can be tested because it's not
changing on a regular basis as I said
the capacity of a cell is defined by the
number of clusters that are deployed
into it another key part of the cell
based architecture is how it gives you
haier MTBF or higher main time between
failures the probability of an outage is
also lower with cells now they have a
consistent cap size so every day is not
a new adventure because you know exactly
this is my cell size and you keep
testing that again and again so the mean
time between failures is lot less in
that sense and another advantage is the
mean time to repair cells are also
easier to recover because the number of
hosts that you are touching or the
operating system that need to be patched
for a particular cause is much smaller
and so the repair is lot quicker as well
and last but not the least one of the
big advantages of cells is higher
availability now of course you have a
system with n cells so possibly n errors
but then one n it the impact and but the
higher MTBF and a lower MTTR
really gives us to that better recovery
ability and overall a higher
availability so these are some of the
advantages of a cell based architecture
and this is exactly how Amazon eks is

this cross account en I wants we also
